description: A species of flowering plant in the mulberry family, known as the common fig. It is the source of the fruit also called the fig and as such is an important crop in those areas where it is grown commercially. Native to the Mediterranean and western Asia.
seasons: Late Summer to Early Autumn (fresh figs have a short season)
healthBenefits: Good source of dietary fiber, promoting digestive health and preventing constipation.
Contains minerals like potassium and calcium, important for bone health and blood pressure regulation.
Rich in antioxidants, which can help protect against chronic diseases.
Dried figs are a concentrated source of nutrients and energy.

potentialAllergies.name: Fig Allergy / Latex Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: Some people may be allergic to figs, possibly due to cross-reactivity with birch pollen or latex. Symptoms can include itching or oral allergy syndrome.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Temperate to subtropical, thrives in areas with long, hot summers and mild winters. Some varieties are more cold-hardy.
2. Soil: Adaptable to various soils but prefers well-drained, fertile loam. Tolerates slightly alkaline conditions.
3. Propagation: Easily propagated from cuttings. Can also be grown from seeds, but quality may vary.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun. Can be grown in containers, especially in colder regions.
5. Watering: Young trees require regular watering. Mature trees are relatively drought-tolerant but produce better fruit with consistent moisture, especially during fruit development.
6. Fertilizing: Generally light feeders. A balanced fertilizer in spring may be beneficial.
7. Pruning: Prune during dormancy to shape the tree, remove dead wood, and encourage fruit production (figs often fruit on new and old wood, depending on variety).
8. Harvesting: Figs are harvested when they are soft to the touch, droop slightly on the stem, and have fully developed color. They do not ripen much after picking.
growthDuration: Trees from cuttings can start bearing fruit in 1-3 years. Figs typically have two crops per year in suitable climates (breba crop on old wood, main crop on new wood).
sustainabilityTips: Fresh figs are highly perishable; store in the refrigerator and consume within a few days.
Dried figs have a long shelf life and are a good way to preserve the fruit.
Enjoy fresh figs with their skin; wash thoroughly.
carbonFootprintInfo: Moderate. Fresh figs can have a higher footprint if air-freighted due to perishability (0.8-2.0 kg CO2e/kg). Dried figs generally have a lower footprint.

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Figs with Prosciutto and Balsamic Glaze
staticRecipes.description: An elegant appetizer combining sweet figs, salty prosciutto, and tangy balsamic.
ingredients: 8-12 ripe fresh figs, halved or quartered
2 tbsp balsamic glaze (store-bought or homemade by reducing balsamic vinegar)
Fresh basil leaves or microgreens for garnish (optional)
steps: Wash figs gently and pat dry. Cut them in half or quarters depending on size.
Arrange fig pieces on a serving platter.
Drape pieces of prosciutto around or over the figs.
Garnish with fresh basil or microgreens if desired. Serve immediately.

staticRecipes.name: Baked Figs with Goat Cheese and Honey
staticRecipes.description: A warm, delicious dessert or appetizer featuring sweet figs and creamy goat cheese.
ingredients: 1 tbsp chopped walnuts or pecans, toasted (optional)
steps: Wash figs. Cut a small 'X' into the top of each fig, about halfway down, without cutting all the way through.
Gently open the fig slightly at the cuts to create a small pocket.
Stuff each fig with a small amount of goat cheese.
Arrange the stuffed figs in a small baking dish.
Bake for 10-15 minutes, or until the figs are softened and the goat cheese is warm and slightly melted.
Sprinkle with toasted nuts (if using) and an extra drizzle of honey before serving warm.

staticRecipes.name: Fig and Almond Smoothie
staticRecipes.description: A nutritious and flavorful smoothie made with fresh or dried figs.
ingredients: 4-5 fresh ripe figs (or 3-4 dried figs, soaked in hot water for 15 mins and drained)
steps: If using fresh figs, remove stems and roughly chop. If using dried figs, ensure they are soft from soaking.
Combine figs, almond milk, frozen banana, almond butter, vanilla extract, and cinnamon in a blender.
Blend until smooth and creamy. Add ice cubes if a colder, thicker smoothie is desired and blend again.
Pour into a glass and serve immediately.
